California has community property laws. So, in a divorce a woman isn't left destitute or at the mercy of the court. There's no need to show fault because the money and property is split - fifty fifty. Then child support and equality of investment in education and getting up to speed in employment compensation brings a little more justice to the situation.
New York has alimony laws, the court decides how much and it's usually quite a bit less.
So I'll bet you will get no-fault divorce but you won't get equality in the division of property or anything near justice after that. There are very real differences in subcultures in how they expect marriage to be treated. Best you should stick with those who have the same expectations you do. And make sure your judges are of the same kind.

@3.Dave
If the law passed, it would save lots of trouble for the married couple to get divorced. True. Marriage is about love between those two. When the love was gone, the foundation of the marriage disappeared.
But consider people who are in love and haven’t got married yet. What would the new law potentially mean to them? Inevitably, for the former group, easier divorce leads to easier marriage. People tend to consider less when they get married, because they can get divorced when either of them think their marriage “broken down for six months or more ‘irretrievably’, without the need to identify a fault, like adultery or abandonment”. People’s commitment to a marriage and a family is likely to go down even before they get married.

Coming to NY from California (many, many years ago), I was shocked to learn about -- what seemed like -- prehistoric NY divorce laws. Obviously, poor people and certain vulnerable people suffer the most from them. Its' a bad, bad case of the State legislating morals.

As for concern about children--believe me I know--its usually far more damaging to be subjected to daily life in a disfunctional, hostile, intact family. Long-term emotional damage, I mean. Children should not be used as an excuse to regulate marriage and divorce in the way that the pro-fault side seems to advocate.

President Obama was spot on. Not only do we need to make sure the victims of this disaster receive financial assistance but we need to move toward a clean energy economy that reduces the need to use/rely so heavily on fossil fuels.

The speech however, missed the details - how are we going to get there? President Obama should use this heightened awareness to push the Senate to pass a comprehensive energy and climate bill that is aggressive in directing resources from fossil energy toward carbon free sources of energy - the House bill does this, the Senate bill does not. This is a chance to pass real energy policy, not just "what can be passed before an election" policy.

The American public is asking for more and expects more from our elected officials.

All of these issues - oil spill, corporate malfeasance, poor coverage, and many of the comments show the central problem underneath: a lack of character. The Greatest Generation sacrificed so much because, as my 86 year old mother would say about the Great Depression, "Yes, we were poor, but we were all poor together." That is the value that is missing: we are all in this together. Much of the rage I see stems, I think, from helplessness--we are watching 2,520,000 gallons of oil spill each and every day (60,000 barrels X 42 gallons per barrel), and not only do we need our President to take action, we also need him to call on us to sacrifice. We should pay a gas tax, each one of us. We should pay $1.00 per plastic bag, each one of us. We should have an individual version of FDR's Victory Gardens. We should write letters to our Congressional Representatives and Senators and demand funding for clean energy and an end to sweetheart deals of oil leases. President Obama, ask us to act, and give us specific actions and goals and targets for each one of us to reach. And then, do what we, the people, cannot do: implement executive orders and push, push, push legislation. Write an executive order demanding that the military fund even 10% of its energy costs by using clean energy. Demand that military housing use solar panels. Instruct governments of states, cities and towns to revamp their building codes, or ask us to demand that our city council do it.

And it is not only for the people whom you speak--it is for the creatures of the sea and the sea itself. Ask us to ACT, Mr. President. And while we are waiting, what is one thing you can do? Today, and every day, to reduce your energy use? Can you try one of the suggestions posted above? Can you post your own - in fact, every time you post on the NY Times or any blog, can you present one suggestion that is manageable and that people can do?

If you are angry, then channel your anger into a productive use. Whether you are Republican, Democrat, Libertarian - who cares? We are Americans, and in our past, we have risen to crises time and time again by pulling together. It's long past time to pull together again.

One last suggestion: throw out your tv. If that is too much, then try unplugging it one day a week. For that matter, unplug your appliances anyway - it actually saves energy as appliances continue to use power even when they are not in use. So make your morning coffee, and unplug your coffee maker.

As a fellow American, I am calling on all of us to rise to the occasion, to work together to solve our problems, to do our part, no matter how small, to reduce our energy use. We can do it. We can do it starting right now.

And for those who pray, yes, do that too.

Since I continue to believe that the President is a very bright individual, with emphaty and compassion for the people and animals damaged by the spill I want to give him all the benefit of doubt.  But, I am getting sick and tired of the charade.  I know Secretary Chu quite well, he and I have worked in the same field of physics.  Putting him in charge of the effort to plug the leak is nonsense and I certainly hope that he has not been in charge, other than in a symbolic sense.  A petroleum engineer with expertise and experience in drilling and completion needs to be in  charge with the best expertise in the country from industry, academia, and national labs at his/her side.  The oil recovery projects needs to be led by folks who know how to manage complex projects.  The oil clean up needs to be managed by folks who have done this before, using the best talent in industry, academia, state and federal governmens.  Need someone who can simplify the overlapping authority of more than a dozen federal agencies...a single person.  The Coast Guard admiral is a terrific guy, but even he can either oversee the clean up or provide information to infinite number of reporters, politicians and the President, and be a tour guide.  One ususally assigns those tasks to PR folks and not to the critically needed incident commander. Instead of beating up BP it would be more useful to work with BP and help the flow of funds to the people who need to be paid for lost income.  On and on, this President has not been a leader, but the complainer and blame master in chief.  I am sick of it.   This is not the time to propose yet more grandois programs and projects, now the focus should be in making the government work for the people and demonstrate the capacity to be efficient and effective on  a grand scale.  Then it is time to propose new intiatives, once the capacity to execute has been demonstrated.  It is sorely missing.

In my view:

1. The President deserves more credit for his speech than most seem to be giving him.

2. This oil spill was a disaster for which the government has been totally unprepared. That lack of preparation goes back decades. Obama is the President least responsible for that lack of preparation. Moreover, given the numerous substantial emergencies left in the wake of the Bush administration, it is grossly unfair to pin the lack of progress in energy and in environmental protection and in work place safety upon Obama.

3. The President was no more capable of meaningfully addressing this oil spill in its first few weeks than most of us would have been. The people who created and operated the drilling system were, obviously, way beyond their own depth, and did not have the tools to arrest the process. The agencies charged with supervising worker and environmental safety were steeped in conflict of interest and mis-feasance and non-feasance and, perhaps, mal-feasance. I have yet to see any of the critics making clear what they expected the President to do - other that in the expression of vague generalities.

4. It bears repeating the obvious: some of the sharpest critics are those who were recently chanting "drill baby drill", and who are hastening to proclaim that this spill should not result in stringent regulation.

5. The President has unequivocally taken responsibility for minimizing the damage, enforcing the obligations of BP, coming to the aid of the many people and places that are being hurt, and adopting regulations to reduce the future likelihood of such disasters, while moving forward on programs to develop alternate energy sources and reduced energy consumption. He may not be as specific in all of this as some would like, but he is probably as specific as prudence and honesty will permit.

6. I say all of this as an Obama supporter who would like to see him be less intent on compromise and more willing to aggressively lead in the direction of change. In that regard, I must keep reminding myself that many Congressional members of his party are almost as beholden to the same special interests as are many Republicans.

7. I hope that those who criticize the President, as regards his approach to the oil spill, will start their criticism with the words: " He should have said . . . .", and end with the words, " I know this would work because . . . "

Let's work with our President and let's make clear to all that we expect our legislators to give him their full support, while exercising proper oversight, unsullied by hypocrisy and opportunism.

HJBoitel

I grrr'ed a bit when the President wandered from the oil spill issue to bemoan our "inaction" on reducing fossil fuel dependence. Come on, there has been plenty of action over the years. Energy bills come out of Congress regularly, as well as tighter CAFE standards, grants to auto manufacturers for research into hydrogen-fueled vehicles, wind power subsidies, etc. The problem isn't lack of action, but lack of results. The last thing I want to see is another unwieldy, results-20-years-down-the-road energy bill rushed out of Congress to prove that we're "doing something".

We need a paradigm shift. Although it would be a tall order, politically speaking, a straight carbon tax would work wonders. Not just levied on businesses and utilities, but on every individual's use of electricity, gasoline and natural gas. People do change their behavior when energy costs rise: the summer of 2008, with its 5-dollar-per-gallon gasoline, saw a significant (if temporary) drop in national consumption.

When it is time to propose something on energy my wish would be that he would propose an R&D effort and not a deployment effort. A Manhattan Project like effort to find efficient and cost effective energy alternatives for oil. Set agressive goals, like 100 mpg light weight vehicles that can fit the needs of Americans, which due to our country's longer commute distances and lack of public transportation are different that those in Europe or Japan, for example.

The new approach HAS to be to pay the real cost of energy. Now don't calling that idea socialist, communist, or gansterist as some of you did before. All the evidence is that by tax dodges, subsidies, and simply passing costs on to others (like the cost of restoring valleys when mountains are cut away to yield coal) we are underpaying. The Gulf is one goof where BP will pay, but we should all pay through what we consume.
What else is lurknig? Besides coal mine deaths, what about the socialistic sharing of risks of nuclear power (Price Anderson Liability Limitation), the various tax subsidies for ethanol, Priuses and now electric cars, etc. Why do we keep making the cost of energy or using energy lower than it really is?

Changing that would be revolutionary, but Pres. Ford, Carter, and Clinton all struck out with this idea that we should de-socialize energy and pay for what we get..so that we get what we pay for.

All of you talk about nuclear, off shore oil, coal to liquids, renewables, and they are all out there but they cannot compete with cheap oil, gas, and coal. The country has struggled with this hangup since before the first oil crisis. The fossil fuels and nuclear industries, to their discredit, play the friend of the poor when someone wants to tax energy. The result is risking drilling, mines that explode, and we hope nothing more.

But all of us should ask- are we more or less at risk economically because of environmental risks? The answer is our economic risks are larger.

Will the President change course?

Lee Schipper
